data.title: Hitting arrow down after ctrl+left does not take current position into account
data.body:
- **VSCode Version**: 1.11.2
- **OS**: Arch Linux

1. Open a python file
2. Write the following in it:

```py
tuples = (
	(1, 12345),
	(1, 67890),
)
```

Move the cursor to be right after `5` in the first `12345`. If you now press <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>←</kbd> followed by <kbd>↓</kbd>, the cursor will end up right after `0` instead of right before `6`, where you would expect it to be (and where it would be by hitting arrow left 5 times instead of previous word).

Moved from VSCodeVim/Vim#1664

data.title: In Pascal-like languages begin-end brackets incorrectly match words containing them as parts
data.body:
When defining Pascal-like language, with begin-end brackets, editor thinks, that "begin" and "end" being parts of any other words are also brackets.
I have tried to use regular expression for brackets, however, it seems that regex is not supported there.

![match](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23244522/25773124/b42aef54-3280-11e7-8c39-d331cc745adf.png)

"language-configuration.json":
![lang-conf](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23244522/25773129/c036890c-3280-11e7-9579-64250864713c.png)

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy any language extension to custom extensions folder
2. In "language-configuration.json" add "begin-end" brackets
3. Write in a new file "begin-end" block and "appendElem" function call inside that block
4. Click on "begin" and see that it matches with function call

data.title: Dimming of inactive group and tab makes text unreadable
data.body:
vscode: 1.12

I'm trying to work with the new theming colors; however, it seems that the dimming of the inactive tab in an inactive group is greater than before?

I can't seem to find a combination that is readable unless I make the inactive tab color `#FFFFFF` which then makes it way too bright when the group is active.

data.title: Bad string encoding when commiting with git
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.1
- OS Version: Fedora 25 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable GPG signing for git with `git config --global commit.gpgsign true`
2. Set a git username containing an accented character with `git config --global user.name 'Something with an 'é' for example`
3. Stage one or more files for commiting in VSCode
4. Try to commit

The result in the git output channel is like this:
![git-commit-vscode](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7602755/25771407/5e6674e2-3250-11e7-8009-f526745fea75.png)
It looks like a typical wrong encoding used somewhere, leading to non-ASCII characters not being used properly.

Committing from an external terminal or the embedded one in the same situation works fine on the other hand.

data.title: Theming: Bracket matching colors
data.body: Bracket matches in the editor use a hardcoded color here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/bracketMatching/browser/bracketMatching.css#L8

data.title: Theming: Minimap slider
data.body: All the colors for the minimap slider are hardcoded in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/browser/viewParts/minimap/minimap.css#L17 and should probably take their colors from the scrollbar colors we already have.

data.title: Vscode 1.12 no longer obeys 'sortText' in completion items (from language server)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: VSCode Version: 1.12 (latest today May 5th 2017)
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install this vsix file: http://s3-test.spring.io/sts4/vscode-extensions/snapshots/vscode-concourse-0.0.2-201705052220.vsix
2. Create a text file called 'pipeline.yml' and put this text in it:

```
resources:
- name: fff
  type: foo
  <*>
```

The `<*>` marks the spot where to put the cursor. So delete it, and put your cursor there.

Press CTRL-SPACE to invoke content assist.

The order of the content assist items that appears in vscode 1.11 is like this and is the correct order:

- check_every
- source
- ← groups
- ← jobs
- ← resource_types
- ← - name

After updating to vscode 1.12 today, the order changed to this:

- ← groups
- ← jobs
- ← resource_types
- ← - name
- check_every
- source

The completion items my extension produces explicitly sets a `sortText` to get exactly the desired ordering. Somehow, it seems like VScode 1.12 no longer consults the sort text but instead just uses the label for sorting. I double-checked that my extension indeed sets the sort-text. Below is some log output showing `${sortText}:${label}` for these completion items as 'proof'.

```
00000: check_every
00001: source
00002: ← groups
00003: ← jobs
00004: ← resource_types
00005: ← - name
```

data.title: Out-of-the-box SCM experience needs improvements

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: - VSCode Version: Code 1.12.1 (f6868fce3eeb16663840eb82123369dec6077a9b, 2017-05-04T21:26:50.689Z) - OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393 - Extensions: none --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Fresh VS Code install 2. `git` is not installed 3. create an empty directory 4. cd into the just created directory 5. launch vscode 6. Go to SCM viewlet This is what I get. There is no indication of what I can or should do next. By comparison, if `git` is on the path I get a more reasonable experience:
